content:
Nice clash.

One tricky thing is that 'Christmas Shopping' has a unique quirk in that it has 'Wine' and 'MulledWine'.

I got this in Shortest mode and was failing this test, but then got 100% on validators.

I went for a RegEx solution that scraped the item name, and its price1 and price2 from LookAheads. But 'MulledWine' broke my lookahead logic and I couldn't figure it out in-clash.

Not sure if you'd want to get rid of it (make the clash easier) or add a matching validator (make it harder), but thought I'd let you know.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Definitely doable in 5 min (at least in languages with a built-in map / dict data structure). Formatting the output correctly can always take 1 or 2 tries (if you're in a hurry and don't read properly), but that applies to all clashes with a numeric answer.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good! Not too difficult for a clash, and I think the new wording makes it very clear and understandable.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple clash involving conditional aggregation and rounding

- Consider rephrasing the goal as: "... indeed the case! First calculate the <<percentage increase in price>> ([[price2]] - [[price1]]) / [[price1]] for each item that appears on both receipts, then <<average the percentage increases>> to estimate the inflation."
Not sure whether "percentage increase" is a known mathematical formula, but I think you can safely remove the helper equation.

- The note "There is always at least one item that appears on both lists." should go into the Constraints section. Please also change "lists" to "receipts".

- Please rephrase the output as: "The estimated inflation, expressed as a percentage ({{%}}) rounded to the nearest 0.01%"

I think the puzzle concept is good, but the first part of the note is a bit confusing to me. Perhaps there is a better way to word it such that it isn't speaking in the negative (as in "don't" do xyz), but still tells you to calculate it on a per item basis?

Input
* Please change "Line N1 + 1" to "Next line", and "old receipt" to "new receipt".

Output
* Please change "2 digits after the dot" to "0.01% (the answer should end with {{%}})".

Constraints
* Please add:
No duplicate [[item]]s in the individual receipts.

Cases
* Christmas Shopping (Test 4): "Steak" appears twice in the new receipt.

* Validator 4: "Steak" appears twice in the old receipt.

* Are you going to include cases where the output is 0.00% or negative? If yes, please add these two situations as two new test-validator pairs. If not, please add a constraint stating that negative or zero outputs will not occur.

Thanks.
Thanks for the feedback - I made the changes. Good spot on the Steak! Guess I didn't have a nice one in a while! Opted for keeping the inflation positive :-)
Rephrased the goal and moved the note to the constraints. I think it should be pretty clear from the example how the output should be formatted, but I'll amend that as well...

Thanks for the feedback! I can see that for Shortest mode this can be challenging and changed the title of TestCase 4 to "MulledWine" in the hope that this will sufficiently highlight the potential issue. I changed Butter to ButterBeer on the corresponding Validator, which is going to break your shortest mode solution (sorry :P).
Nice, thank you. I was just being explicit on rounding to *the nearest* 0.01%, which was omitted in your original output.

Constraints
* As @User123 mentioned, please change "lists" to "receipts" ðŸ˜‰

Thanks.

No problem ðŸ™‚
Have a nice steak! ðŸ˜‰
because of the high inflation I can only afford fish fingers :p
